titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Sugoroku (Japanese Board Games) collection, 1896-circa 1950s RL.11796

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-07-26 16:06:34 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.unittitle: Sugoroku (Japanese board games) collection
did.abstract: Sugoroku are Japanese games similar to snakes and ladders, which in the late 19th and early 20th centuries were sometimes included in newspapers and children's magazines. Includes 26 sugoroku games (some items are double-sided), primarily dating from the 1910s to 1930s, with a few earlier and later.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: すごろく, or sugoroku, are Japanese games similar to "snakes and ladders". These types of games typically involve numbered squares, which players navigate from bottom to top using dice, and where there may be "ladders" allowing a climb ahead or "snakes" causing a fall behind. Sugoroku may vary in structure and game play, and often include instructions on how to play. In the Meiji, Taisho, and early Showa periods (1890s-1940s and later), sugoroku games were sometimes included as inserts in newspapers and children's magazines.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Sugoroku (Japanese Games) collection was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as purchases in 2019, from Asia Bookroom in 2021, from Daša Pahor, Ph.D., & Alexander Johnson, Ph.D. in 2021, from Rose Counsell Hozuki Books in 2022, and from Joe Fay McBride Rare Books in 2023.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Sugoroku (Japanese Games) collection, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Sara Biondi and Tracy M. Jackson, February 2020
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2019-0007, 2020-0036, 2021-0117, 2022-0007, 2022-0109, 2023-0033
Updated by Tracy M. Jackson and Matthew Hayes, December 2021 and February 2022.
Updated by Tracy Jackson and Sara Biondi, July 2023.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Includes 26 sugoroku games (some items are double-sided), primarily dating from the 1910s to 1930s, with a few earlier and later. Many games have a military theme, but others themes include animals, science, Hollywood actors, and travel.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: 興亜ナカヨシスゴロク : 幼年俱樂部新年號附錄 / Kōa nakayoshi sugoroku : Yōnen kurabu shinnengō furoku, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.
日満交驩大双六. / Nichi-Man ko kan dai sugoroku, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.
歐訪大飛行記念飛行遊戯. / Ōhō daihikō kinen hikō yūgi, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

did.unittitle: 漫画双六 世界早のぞき (Manga sugoroku Sekai hayanzoki)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher: Publisher not indicated (likely 新愛知 / Shin-Aichi);
Other names associated: 堤寒三 (Tsutsumi Kanzō - art);

Other Notes: Came as bonus with 新愛知 (Shin-Aichi) (serial title) no. 4129. Appears to be this item: https://www.asiabookroom.com/pages/books/163414/kanzo-tsutsumi/manga-sugoroku-sekai-hayanozoki-a-brief-peek-at-the-world;
Dimensions: 80 x 53 cm;
Date as written: Showa 6

Other names associated: 明石赤子(Akashi Akako - art), 日本少年編輯局 (Nihon shōnen henshūkyoku - concept);
Summary of Game: Take off and land your plane safely. Two routes (red and blue). Play instructions included on board;
Other Notes: Came as a bonus with 日本少年 (Nihon shōnen) (serial title) volume 7, issue 1;
Date as written: Meiji 45, January

did.unittitle: 少年少女譚海 新年号 第ー附録：近代科学戦双六 (Shōnen shōjo tankai shinnengō Dai-ichi furoku: Kindai kagakusen sugoroku)

scopecontent.p: Publisher: not indicated beyond magazine title (少年少女譚海, Shōnen shōjo tankai);
Other names associated: 村上松次郎 (Murakami Matsujirō - art);
Summary of Game: Games are numbered (two-sided board): #1 first side of board, pictures and dice rolls listed, large circle in center "take-off";
Other Notes: Came as bonus with 少年少女譚海 (Shōnen shōjo tankai) (serial title) volume 16, issue 1;
Date as written: Showa 10

did.unittitle: 少年少女譚海 新年号 第３，４，５附録 (Shōnen shōjo tankai shinnengō Dai-san, yon, go furoku)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher: Printer listed, but no publisher other than magazine title (Shōnen shōjo tankai);
Other names associated: 村上松次郎 (Murakami Matsujirō - art), 少年少女譚海 (Shōnen shōjo tankai);

Summary of Game: Games are numbered: #3 大空襲爆撃遊戯 (Dai kūshū bakugeki yūgi) (two-player territory control game, rules included); #4 新案マラソン競争遊戯 (Shin'an marason kyōsō yūgi) (race game around outer red track, rules included); #5 猛獣狩点取遊戯 (Mōjū-gari tentori yūgi) (4-player point-taking big game hunting game. Requires 12 cut-out animal cards, not present; rules included on board);
Other Notes: Came as bonus with 少年少女譚海 (Shōnen shōjo tankai) (serial title) volume 16, issue 1;
Date as written: Showa 10

Map of China and Manchuria printed on reverse.

Other names associated: 稲葉春吉 (Inaba Haruyoshi) appears to be the personal name associated with corporate name スモーヤ Sumo-ya / Sumōya;
Summary of Game: Airplane sugoroku, with spaces for refuling, parachuting, night flying, etc.;
Dimensions: 54 x 38 cm

did.unittitle: 支那事變皇軍大勝 (Shina Jihen kogun taisho sugoroku (front))

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher: 主婦の友 (Shufu no tomo);
Other names associated: 主婦の友編輯局 (Shufu no tomo henshūkyoku - guidance), 嶺田弘 (Mineda Hiroshi - art), illustrator;

Summary of Game: Next to title: 皇軍勇士慰問・銃後家庭慰問 (Kōgun yūshi imon / Jūgo katei imon) "Condolences/sympathy for the brave soldiers of the imperial army, condolences/sympathy for those on the homefront". Sugoroku game about the Sino-Japanese war, interim government of Manchuria, activities supporting the troops at war, etc. Includes un-cut die template and cards with silhouettes of planes, ships, etc.;
Other Notes: Came as a new year's bonus with 主婦の友 for Showa 14, v.23 issue 1.;
Dimensions: 25" x 37"

did.unittitle: お正月の新しい家庭娯楽大特輯 (Oshōgatsu no atarashii katei goraku daitokushū (reverse))

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher: 主婦の友 (Shufu no tomo);
Other names associated: 永鳥眞雄 (Nagatori Sanao) listed under the coin fortune-telling section;

Summary of Game: Variety of games to play at home, includes small board game in center, games to play as a family at home (including "indoor boat race", "bean-throwing battle", "find the spy", etc - many are war/battle-themed), a fortune-telling chart using coins, and fortune-telling based on zodiac animals;
Other Notes: Came as a new year's bonus with 主婦の友 (Shufu no tomo) Showa 14, v.23 issue 1.;
Dimensions: 25" x 37"

did.unittitle: 日本周遊雙六 (Nihon shūyū sugoroku)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher: 博文館 (Hakubunkan);
Other names associated: 水野年方 (Mizuno Toshikata - art), ukiyoe-e and Nihonga artist;

Summary of Game: Travel-themed sugoroku with landmarks/famous locations around Japan, including Ise Grand Shrine, Tokyo, Niigata, Nikko, Izumo Grand Shrine, and notably Ryūkyū, Taiwan ("Japan's new territory/holding after the great success of the Sino-Japanese War" with an image of locals waving Japanese flags & imperial soldiers), Chishima (the contested Kuril islands), and Bakan (the Treaty of Shimonoseki);
Dimensions: 24.5" x 35"

did.unittitle: 征空すごろく、世界航空路圖 (Seizora sugoroku, Sekai kōkū michizu)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher: 大阪毎日新聞 (Ōsaka Mainichi Shinbun);
Other names associated: No attributions given;

Summary of Game: 新時代教育遊戯 (Shin-jidai kyōiku yūgi - a new-era educational game) (subtitle on upper-right of board). This large format color Japanese world map doubles as a 'Sugoroku' gameboard and was issued by the Osaka Mainichi Shinbun newspaper as a 1930 'New Year's Supplement', a special reward to its readers. The stylized map game has players explore every part of the globe by either airplane or Zeppelin airship. adorned with their flags. All major cities are labelled and connected by flight routes, while images of famous aircraft, such as Charles Lindbergh's 'Spirit of St. Louis' (the first plane to cross the Atlantic in 1927) and the German Zeppelin airships, shown crossing the seas. The margins feature photographic images associated with different parts of the world, including buildings, archeological sites, animals, or people in local clothing. In the lower right corner, the map features the directions for playing. 'The Easiest Way', as Interpreted by The David Rumsey Map Collection: "Departing from Osaka [1] and moving to all the places in order of 2, 3, 4, you then return to Tokyo [52]. the player who reaches there first is the winner. "throw the dice and proceed as many places as the number you cast..." In the upper right, text informs players of distances between locations, with basic geographic facts. The legend, toward the bottom of the map oval, shows 5 types of red lines & 1 square: 1. well-known large aircraft route (refers to Zeppelin, seen center of map) 2. first-class limited time route 3. liner air route 4. air route already mastered/controlled/conquered 5. planned route. main localities [red square inside black square]." References: David Rusmey Map Collection: 7926.000.
Other Notes: Came as new year's bonus with 大阪毎日新聞 (Osaka Mainichi newspaper), v.1 no. 6755;
Dimensions: 107 x 77 cm
Sources: dealer description provided by Daša Pahor, Ph.D., & Alexander Johnson, Ph.D.

did.unittitle: 紙名尽寿語六 (Shimei zukushi sugoroku)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher: 伊勢辰 (Isetatsu)
Other namesassociated: none given.

Summary of game: This sugoroku depicts various forms of Japanese paper and papermaking techniques. The red column gives several types of paper, including tanzaku, chiyogami, hōshogami, minogami, ganpishi, torinokogami, fusumagami, and Asakusagami. The starting square depicts two female papermakers at work. The winning square depicts the Seven Gods of Fortune. This sugoroku is considerably smaller by genre standards.
Other Notes: This game board uses an alternative rendering of the term sugoroku. It is rendered as 寿語六, while more typically the term appears as 双六.
Dimensions: 38 x 25 cm.

did.unittitle: 活劇王双六 (Katsugeki Ō Sugoroku)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publisher: ナゴヤ玩具 (Nagoya Omocha)
No other names present on item.
39cm x 54cm
